Ceas'd has the hamlet's distant sound</br>To fluctuate, in the fluttering breeze:</br>And, wandering down the vast profound,</br>Yon orb, enlarging by degrees,</br>With clouds of purple wreaths his brow.</br>And now he sinks, while, o'er the plain below,</br>The sullen shades of night, in mute succession flow.

As o'er yon time-worn turret, gleams</br>Mild evening's solitary star,</br>Wak'd by its soft, its sliver beams,</br>Can fancy curb her airy car?</br>Ah!  can the drowsy god invade,</br>When calm with solitude and silence laid,</br>She rests, propitious CAM, beneath the willowy shade?

Conduct me to the deep retreat</br>Where erst thy godlike bards reclin'd;</br>For now my burning pulses beat,</br>And gorgeous visions fire my mind.</br>My conscious harp, spontaneous, rings,</br>Thy breeze, O parent CAM, benignant, brings</br>New vigour to its frame, new modulates its strings.

While yet I breathe this balmy gale,</br>While yet the willing muse inspires,</br>With solemn awe, I pondering, hail,</br>From far, yon dim-discover'd spires,</br>Where science haunts the classic dome,</br>Where cloister'd study, 'midst the midnight gloom,</br>Collects the scatter'd spoils of Greece and Rome.

Farewell ye meads!  ye honour'd streams!</br>Farewell ye academic shades!</br>With soul intent on mighty themes,</br>Which many a devious step pervades:</br>Where yet, by fond attachment led,</br>Majestic shades the well-known mansions tread,</br>Where, first, ingenuous youth her infant blossoms spread.

Farewell, farewell, thou hallow'd soil!</br>Ye gothic roofs, ye hoary spires!</br>On life's tumultuous flood to toil,</br>I go where tyrant fate requires.</br>O might thy hand, auspicious peace,</br>From sorrow's chain, my struggling heart release,</br>And bid the fiends of care their rustic clamour cease.

Farewell!  desponding, sad, forlorn,</br>I breathe the solitary lay;</br>And, far to distant regions borne,</br>With lingering step, reluctant, stray.</br>With anxious thought, reflections pale,</br>While tremors strange her fearful heart assail,</br>Lifts, with enfeebled arm, futurity's dull veil.

Long tost through varied scenes, she knows,</br>Round the gay forms of fancy's train,</br>Fictitious hope, thy plumage shows,</br>Thy smiles forebode no future pain.</br>But soon the orient colours die,</br>In vain, to find them, roves the startled eye;</br>Before it's humid orb careering tempests fly.

While wandering through life's dreary vale,</br>Adversity, unfeeling power!</br>Hurls on the wretch, with terror pale,</br>From sorrow's urn, the baleful shower;</br>Nor partial falls the deepening gloom,</br>The slave, the despot mingle in the tomb:</br>The orb of empire wanes, and monarchs mourn its doom.

What hope for man, o'erwhelming war,</br>Uncommon furies in his train,</br>O'er heaps of carnage rolls his car,</br>And Europe mourns her thousands slain:</br>What hope, amidst disastrous days,</br>When freedom's temple totters to its base,</br>And, with earth's vilest brood, dishonour'd science strays!

Night, with her dun barbaric gloom,</br>The moral empire wide o'ershades.</br>How blest the tenant's of the tomb,</br>Whose ears no mortal voice pervades!</br>Yet, fair philosophy, thine eyes,</br>See, from the flames, a new-born phoenix rise,</br>And future Edens hail, and gaze with sweet surprise.

From festive throngs, methinks, I hear</br>His voice some boon associate raise,</br>Enough, sad moralist, forbear</br>The tenor of thy mournful lays:</br>And why thy serious numbers pour,</br>Where revels youth, within his roseate bower?</br>Expand the glowing soul, enjoy the present hour.

Awake the strain, for ah!  when past</br>The vernal morn returns no more,</br>And wailful woe's intrusive blast,</br>Resounding, howls on pleasure's shore.</br>Bring, bring Oporto's juice along,</br>With willing speed, convene the jovial throng,</br>Let mirth, and frolic joy, begin the merry song.

Yet, while the jocund notes aspire,</br>O CAM, beside thy reedy streams,</br>Let me, in careless ease, retire,</br>Entranc'd in sweet poetic dreams.</br>As now, along the banks reclin'd,</br>Where thy grey willows chide the wanton wind,</br>Thoughts, in romantic train, invade my pensive mind.

Of yore, o'er this renowned plain,</br>What heroes, sages, patriots stray'd,</br>Who now, in fame's transcendent fane,</br>In gorgeous characters pourtray'd,</br>Flame through the drear abyss of time,</br>And thron'd, in glory's starry robes, sublime,</br>Receive the genial hail of every various clime.

Ha!  midst the evenings sombrous gloom,</br>In sheeny state, august and slow,</br>They rise, with renovated bloom,</br>And rang'd, in long procession, go.</br>Dim seen, through twilight's dusky veil,</br>Smooth, up the void, the forms aerial sail,</br>While round them, breaths the breath of heaven's ambrosial gale.

Nature's inimitable laws,</br>Tracing to one harmonious whole,</br>And wandering on from cause to cause,</br>See Bacon's philosophic soul.</br>While error clanks her slavish chain,</br>Reviving science lights her torch again,</br>And crowns her hero's front, and hails her future reign.

Plung'd in the depth of thought profound,</br>Great Newton his intrepid gaze,</br>From orb to orb directing round,</br>Th' expanded universe surveys.</br>Immortal truth's unclouded ray</br>Pours, round his steadfast steps, eternal day,</br>And, o'er his hoary brows the lambent lightnings play.

In morals as in arts supreme,</br>Clarke, thy seraphic mind I hail.</br>Let bigots mark its placid stream,</br>Unmov'd by passion's wayward gale.</br>They cannot stem oblivion's wave,</br>But thou, in memory's purest font, shall lave,</br>And burst, with soary wing, the bondage of the grave.

Borne on the pinions of the breeze,</br>But hark!  celestial music sighs.</br>Ah!  peace with yonder tossing trees!</br>Ye brawling billows cease to rise!</br>With frenzied eyes, replete with fire,</br>Poetic genius leads the tuneful quire,</br>And sounds her epic trump, and kindles fierce desire.

With fame's reluctant laurels crown'd,</br>Sweet Eden's poet next appears,</br>Maeonian measures, all around,</br>Resounding, strike my ravish'd ears,</br>As o'er the strings his fingers rove,</br>Fantastic forms, in gay succession, move,</br>The purple pomp of war, the paradise of love.

Smooth Mulla's bard now, lonely, strays,</br>With doric reed, midst rural charms;</br>And now his martial lyre displays</br>Regions  of blood, and clash of arms.</br>Round, in th' enchanter's subtil chain,</br>Heroic hearts, in mournful verse complain,</br>And halls, and wizzard bowers, adorn the fairy plain.

I see satyric Dryden rear,</br>High on his front, the splendid ray;</br>And hush'd in awful transport, hear</br>Thy pealing harp Pindaric Gray.</br>Attention bends to Cowley's strain,</br>Familiar Prior leads his comic train,</br>Or paints the woes of man, the progeny of pain.

Nurse of each thought erect and bold,</br>Sweet poesy, whose fervid fire</br>Prompted the genuine sons of old,</br>With happiest hands, to sweet the lyre,</br>Parent of virtue!  haste along,</br>Like them instruct me o'er the listening throng,</br>From passion's flood, to pour the torrent of the song.

How blythe the season when, of yore,</br>Crowding along the wintry blaze,</br>I learnt the legendary lore</br>Of the grey gossip's tragic lays.</br>Oh, tell!  what mightier strain can, now,</br>Make the rude soul with such emotion glow,</br>Or bid the bounding blood with equal vigour flow.

Wandering, I mourn'd the buried brave,</br>Careless of night's unsocial noon,</br>When slept upon the glimmering wave,</br>The splendour of the summer's moon.</br>Ah, happy days!  serene and clear!</br>In memory's flattering glass, your charms appear</br>Ting'd with the richest blooms of life's inconstant year.

Be still, thou voice, whose friendly tone</br>Foretells the poet's scanty fare.</br>He will not pour the hopeless moan,</br>Visions of bliss when you are there.</br>Can all the floods of wealth impart</br>The balm which softens woe's severest smart,</br>The philosophic calm, the sunshine of the heart?

Luxurious plenty, spread thy board,</br>And wave thy rod, despotic power,</br>And avarice, heap thy sordid hoard,</br>Tempests of care around you lour.</br>My heart no envious pangs invade,</br>From pride, from pomp, in slavish garb array'd,</br>I fly, with temperate hope, to freedom's holy shade.

Blest, if with years of pleasing toil,</br>I might to Britain's distant bowers,</br>From Greece, from Rome's paternal soil,</br>Transplant some solitary flowers.</br>Thrice blest, if to my dazzled sight,</br>Some happy hand might raise, serene and bright,</br>Thy star of science, CAM, rich with redoubled light.

Alert, beneath its humble shed,</br>My joyous soul should still exclaim,</br>O wider yet and wider spread,</br>Fair orb, thine energizing flame.</br>While Europe, with incessant gaze,</br>Pours the loud pean of tumultuous praise,</br>And warns her smiling realms beneath thy boundless blaze.

But ah!  ye visions of delight!</br>Too fast your tarnish'd splendour fades!</br>Ye sink!  ye vanish from my sight!</br>While factions deep and dreary shades</br>Descend, while freedom, wan with care,</br>Flies from the hostile roof, with scattered hair,</br>And fetter'd genius comes her gloomy grief to share.

History, thy doleful valves unfold,</br>Bring forth the great of every age,</br>In blood their goary garments roll'd,</br>The martyrs of imperial rage.</br>The servile chain, the rod of power,</br>With baleful influence, blast the muse's power,</br>They haste to happier climes, and shun th' oppresive hour.

'Twas thus, when Greece, in ruin, laid,</br>Prostrate, beneath the tyrant's arm.</br>They sought Ausonian freedom's shade,</br>Each breast with patriot passions warm.</br>Albion, they linger round thine isles.</br>Wishful, they gaze her fane where virtue piles,</br>And, o'er th' Atlantic waste, a new creation smiles.

Let Europe, CAM, with hidious mien,</br>Light persecution's frightful fire.</br>Amid the general storm serene,</br>Bid thou the new-born thought aspire.</br>Let not thine hand its course controul,</br>Unbounded bid the seas of science roll;</br>Nor bind, in slavery's chain, the bold the vigorous soul.

Why should the gloom of antient years</br>O'ercloud the day-spring of the mind?</br>In youth renew'd, dispel thy fears,</br>And cast the wither'd slough behind.</br>Amidst mortality's drear maze,</br>From hope's high cliff, let virtue's beacons blaze,</br>And, up perfection's steep, thine eye insatiate raise.

Wherever truth and reason meet,</br>Wherever worth, deserted, strays,</br>Do thou afford a generous seat,</br>And clasp them, with a friend's embrace.</br>Thine be the truly liberal plan,</br>And, dauntless, in the philosophic van,</br>Assert, with steady zeal, the dignity of man.</br>
